H0.text: Leaves are the part of a compost pile that break down materials and add nutrients to the soil, as compost piles contain leaves, moisture, vegetables, and microorganisms.

H1.text: Moisture is the part of a compost pile that breaks down materials and adds nutrients to the soil, while other parts include leaves, vegetables, and microorganisms.

H2.text: Vegetables are the part of a compost pile that breaks down materials and adds nutrients to the soil, alongside leaves, moisture, and microorganisms.

H3.text: Microorganisms break down materials and add nutrients to the soil in a compost pile.

A4.text: Bacteria are the most abundant and important of all the microorganisms found in compost. Bacteria process carbon and nitrogen and excrete plant-available nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and magnesium.

A5.text: Fungi such as molds and yeasts help break down materials that bacteria cannot, especially cellulose and lignin in woody material.
